bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, December 8, 1929

div1.p: Carter discusses Frost's final editing of the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever and her hope that the book might be completed and published early the next year.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, December 8, 1929
div1.opener:
Book Misel, Russell
(Report)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
December 8, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Your good letter of November 27th. was awaiting me here on
my return from a three days stay in Baltimore with the Frosts.

As usual, Dr. Frost was extremely busy. However, on Thanks-
giving night he took off time to go over and discuss the maps and
other accumulated material and problems that I had brought over with me.
As I told you, in my letter of November 24th., one of the things I es-
pecially wished to get cleared up was what Dr. Frost wanted done about
these maps before having them inked in. I am glad to say that he was
much pleased with the work done on the maps this summer, although he
wishes some minor changes made. These I have already blocked out in
pencil and will shortly get in proper shape for the completion of the
maps.

Dr. Frost and I also decided that a third map, considerably
smaller that the other two, should be inserted in the book at the
place dealing with the expeditions of Ojeda, Nicuesa et al. This would
be practically a XVIth. Century “shore line map” of that part of the
Caribbean literal comprising part of Colombia: “Darien:” Panama: Nice-
ragus and, possible, Honduras. I am therefore now engaged in working
up the data for this map--considerably more of an undertaking than for
the previous two, because of the chronological limitations. It in-
volves quite a good deal of reading as well as the examination of such
XVIth. Century maps already in existence as are available. nNone of whichthese individually have,
so far, been found to contain all the data needed for our argument in
Section iii, part i (con.) “Other Parts of America.” When this has been
worked up, however, the map will be much simpler for the cartographer to
draw than were the previous two.

Dr. Frost still hopes to finish the final editing of Father's
MS by the end of the year, if nothing unforeseen happens. I hardly
think that possible as he left for New York the Sunday after Thanks-
giving and also had a trip to Canada in prospect before Xmas. However,
it does sound as if , to quote from your last letter, we may hope for the
completion of the Introduction and editing “before very long.” Of course,
even after that, there will be the final typing, which Dr. Frost said you
had agreed should be done under his supervision at the School of Hygiene.
There will also be the reading of this final typewritten copy: by Dr.
Frost for the text, and by Miss Brown and myself for typographical errors,
especially in the bibliography and in the quotations in foreign lan-
guages. This same procedure should be followed in the galley and page
proof, in addition to that of the routine work of the professional proof
readers of the publisher. All of this, of course, means a “hang-over”
into 1930, but once the Introduction and editing are completed the rest
should be “plain sailing.” and also, I believe, “fast sailing,” i. e.
more or less mechanical things, which can be pushed as Dr. Frost's pres-
ent work cannot be.

I had hoped much last spring that the book would be “between
covers” by Xmas. That hope “died hard,” but I earnestly trust that the
New Year may be kinder than the Old and that we shall “make port” before
very long.”
With all manner of good wishes, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway.
New York, N. Y.
